item.title: Eyewitness misidentification is the leading cause of wrongful...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Eyewitness misidentification is the leading cause of wrongful convictions, which are fueled by unreliable and discriminatory identification procedures.

#CAAPV supports HB 21-1142, which would require law enforcement to update policies to reflect the best practices in conducting show up identifications, limit the admissibility of show up identifications that are not properly conducted, and require data collection on the use of show up IDs. Call/write your representative and urge them to support this bill!

Together Colorado was live.

No matter what we look like or where we‚Äôre from, we all want to know we can make it home safely to our families at the end of the day. This legislative session,... we have an opportunity to uphold justice for all by limiting and standardizing the policing practice known as ‚Äúshowups" with HB21-1142.

A ‚Äúshowup‚Äù is an unreliable identification procedure used by law enforcement where a lone individual is presented in person to an eyewitness to determine if that individual committed the crime. Showups are inherently unreliable and often discriminatory against BIPOC and low-income people. Nationally, eyewitness misidentification is the leading cause of wrongful convictions.

This bill would:
- Require an update of the current policies and training for showup procedures to reflect the most current recognized best practices
- Require the POST (Peace Officer Standards and Training) Board to certify that law enforcement agencies have adopted the policies
- Limit the admissibility of showup eyewitness identifications in court if not conducted properly
- Require data collection on the use of showups by police departments

Alexander coauthored a paper in June in the Journal of Humanistic Psychology, titled, ‚ÄúSick and Shut In: Incarceration During a Public Health Crisis.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of literature discussing the physical and mental health consequences of solitary confinement,‚Äù Alexander said. ‚ÄúIsolation can lead to depression, anxiety, and can cause some cognitive difficulties which intertwine with the physical constraints.
